subject: RE: [junit] Test cases size and design
msgSnippet: I think that the length of a unit test is not the deciding factor, or shouldn t be. I have written unit tests that range from a half dozen lines to two dozen
messageBody:
I think that the length of a unit test is not the deciding factor, or shouldn't be. I have written unit tests that range from a half dozen lines to two dozen lines. The shorter tests were for more easily tested things while the longer tests were for the more complicated test setups.

Assuming that you have factored out any duplicate environment setup code, then just accept that some tests will be longer than others. My criteria as to whether it is a good test is whether it truely helps me find bugs in my code.

Simon

>-----Original Message-----
>From: Robert Wenner [mailto:robert@...]
>Sent: Tuesday, May 07, 2002 2:36 AM
>To: junit@yahoogroups.com
>Subject: [junit] Test cases size and design
>
>
>Hi!
>
>
>I've got some questions on size of test cases and would like to hear
>your opinions.
>
>I write a program matching the board game Carcassonne (see
>http://das-spiel.de/hig/seiten/0245e.htm for a brief summaray).
>In Carcassonne you have tiles showing countryside elements like roads,
>abbeys, and city parts. The game has a specific set of tiles I want to
>create in the program.
>
>I made the constructor of the Tile class private and provided static
>makeTileXyz methods to create tiles.
>
>Now my test methods get quite large. Each of them assures that
>the tile
>has just (and only) the requested features. So each test checks for
>special items on the cards (e.g. isAbbey, isMarketsquare) and counts
>the roads coming in and the city parts a tile has.
>
>In addition tests get more complicated because tiles may be
>rotated in
>the game. The test for makeRoadTurningLeft (ensure the tile shows a
>road turning left) has to check whether the road goes south to west,
>west to north, north to east or east to south. In the end my tests are
>about 20 to 30 lines of code, but I was used to have 5 liners in other
>projects.
>
>What do you think about this test case size?
>
>Would you create additional methods to help in testing, i.e. for
>counting the roads on one tile or a method like isSpecial?
>
>Would you place such helpers in the test class (as they are only used
>for testing)? Does that get to complex, i.e. do you eventually need
>test cases for your test cases?
>
>Would you rely on some orientation of created tiles, e.g. assume the
>left turning road is always constructed as from east turning to south
>(maybe this is like the Blackbox / Whitebox discussion)?
>
>Would you even allow incomplete tests (not testing what is
>"most likely
>working", e.g. assuming a tile does not have special items)?
>
>
>Thanks for your comments.
>
>Robert
